title: Induction - C-magnet - motor pulls bar on rails

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students wish to determine the magnitude <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> of a uniform magnetic field that is generated by the <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>-shaped magnet shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The magnet creates an upward-pointing magnetic field in a rectangular-shaped region between its north and south poles, and negligible magnetic field outside of the rectangular region.

The students have a loop, also shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, made from a straight conducting rod of negligible resistance, and a section of resistive wire that may be connected to and disconnected from the rod as needed. The resistance of the wire is great enough that only small currents can be generated in the loop, resulting in negligible magnetic forces on any part of the loop that is in the magnet’s magnetic field. The rod is longer than the width of the magnetic field region.

Additionally, the students have rulers, metersticks, a motion sensor, an ammeter, and a voltmeter.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine the magnitude <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> of the magnetic field by making a linear graph. Include steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students wish to determine the magnitude <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> of a uniform magnetic field that is generated by the <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>-shaped magnet shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The magnet creates an upward-pointing magnetic field in a rectangular-shaped region between its north and south poles, and negligible magnetic field outside of the rectangular region.

The students have a loop, also shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, made from a straight conducting rod of negligible resistance, and a section of resistive wire that may be connected to and disconnected from the rod as needed. The resistance of the wire is great enough that only small currents can be generated in the loop, resulting in negligible magnetic forces on any part of the loop that is in the magnet’s magnetic field. The rod is longer than the width of the magnetic field region.

Additionally, the students have rulers, metersticks, a motion sensor, an ammeter, and a voltmeter.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine the magnitude <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> of the magnetic field by making a linear graph. Include steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) For the data collected in the procedure from part (a), describe how the students could create a linear graph and how that graph would be analyzed to determine <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math>.

In a magnetism research facility, engineers wish to experimentally determine the magnitude of a uniform, vertical magnetic field <math alttext="vector B sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mn>0</mn></msub></math> created by a device they have built. The field occupies a large region of space, within which the engineers have placed a bar of mass <math alttext="M sub B, equals 0.0400 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.0400</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math> and two horizontal, parallel conducting rails, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The bar is pulled along the rails by a motor, and both the bar and the rails have negligible resistance. The rails are a distance <math alttext="D equals 0.300 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.300</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> apart and are connected at one end by a resistor of resistance <math alttext="R equals 1.20 ohms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mstyle></math>.
With the bar initially at rest, the motor pulls the bar along the rails with a constant force. A motion sensor records the resulting velocity <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> and acceleration <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> of the bar as functions of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>. The engineers select velocity and acceleration data for <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math> specific times during the bar’s motion, creating the data table shown.
<math alttext="t, in seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="v, in meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>m/s</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="a, in meters per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi><mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mo>(</mo><mpadded><msup><mtext>m/s</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="0.050" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.050</mn></math><math alttext="0.26" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.26</mn></math><math alttext="4.37" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.37</mn></math><math alttext="0.150" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.150</mn></math><math alttext="0.67" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.67</mn></math><math alttext="3.55" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.55</mn></math><math alttext="0.300" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.300</mn></math><math alttext="1.04" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.04</mn></math><math alttext="2.33" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.33</mn></math><math alttext="0.500" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.500</mn></math><math alttext="1.39" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.39</mn></math><math alttext="1.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.50</mn></math><math alttext="0.900" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.900</mn></math><math alttext="1.84" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.84</mn></math><math alttext="0.49" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.49</mn></math>Note: <math alttext="M sub B, equals 0.0400 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.0400</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math>, <math alttext="D equals 0.300 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.300</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>, <math alttext="R equals 1.20 ohms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></math>
(c)

i. Indicate what quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="B sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>.

Horizontal axis: _______________          Vertical axis: _______________

Use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities indicated that are not already provided in the table. Label each column and include units.

ii. On the grid in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label all axes, including units. On the same grid, draw a straight line that best represents the data.
(d) Using the line drawn in part (c)(ii), calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="B sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
